title: 104_s270
content: The "Alien Terrorist Removal Act of 1995" allows for the removal of alien terrorists under the Immigration and Nationality Act. The "Alien Terrorist Removal Act of 1995" defines key terms such as 'alien terrorist', 'classified information', 'national security', 'special court', and 'special removal hearing'. The "Alien Terrorist Removal Act of 1995" outlines the procedures for a special removal hearing for alien terrorists present in the United States when deportation poses a national security risk. The "Alien Terrorist Removal Act of 1995" establishes a Special Court with up to seven judges designated by the Chief Justice to hear cases involving classified information related to national security risks. The "Alien Terrorist Removal Act of 1995" establishes a Special Court with up to seven judges designated by the Chief Justice to hear cases involving classified information related to national security risks. When the Attorney General makes the application, a single judge of the special court considers it in camera and ex parte, invoking procedures if probable cause exists. The Alien Terrorist Removal Act of 1995 establishes a Special Court with up to seven judges to hear cases involving national security risks and classified information. Special removal hearings are open to the public, and aliens have the right to be present if probable cause is shown. The Alien Terrorist Removal Act of 1995 establishes a Special Court with up to seven judges to hear cases involving national security risks and classified information. Special removal hearings are open to the public, and aliens have the right to be present if probable cause is shown. The alien has the right to be present at the hearing, be represented by counsel, introduce evidence, cross-examine witnesses, and request subpoenas for witnesses. Counsel may be appointed if the alien is financially unable to obtain representation. The judge can allow the introduction of evidence in camera and ex parte if public disclosure poses a national security risk due to classified information. The judge must provide the alien with a substitution or summary of the evidence in such cases. The judge may provide a summary or substitution of evidence to the alien if public disclosure poses a risk to national security. If the substituted evidence provides the alien with a similar ability to make their defense as the specific evidence, the judge can proceed. If disclosure of specific evidence poses a risk of harm, deportation determination can be made based on substituted evidence. The judge must deport the alien if the Attorney determines deportation is necessary. The judge must require deportation if the Attorney General proves, by clear and convincing evidence, that the alien is subject to deportation under section 241(a)(4)(B). The alien may appeal a determination under subsection (f) to the court of appeals for the Federal Circuit within twenty days. The Attorney General can also appeal a determination under subsection (d), (e), or (f) to the court of appeals for the Federal Circuit within twenty days. When requested by the Attorney General, the entire record of the proceeding shall be transmitted to the court of appeals under seal for consideration in camera and ex parte.
